name: anode production, silicon coated graphite, NMC811, for Li-ion battery | anode, silicon coated graphite, for Li-ion battery | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/24728/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg silicon coated graphite-based anode for Li-ion batteries, used in combination with advance cathodes (e.g. nickel-manganese-cobalt in ratio 8:1:1, NMC811). Data are based on literature and expert judgement. For infrastructure, the ecoinvent dataset "chemical factory, organics" is accounted. This dataset is a copy of the corresponding regional dataset. Production volume was adjusted.

The activity starts when synthetic graphite, silicon and other materials enter the process at the factory.

The activity ends with the production of silicon coated graphite-based anode at factory gate.
category: C:Manufacturing/27:Manufacture of electrical equipment/272:Manufacture of batteries and accumulators/2720:Manufacture of batteries and accumulators

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period is from 2016 (year of the collection of data) and 2020 (year of the dataset)
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The dataset is valid for the production of anode in China, where the data collection occured.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset incudes the production of an anode for a Li-ion battery with advance cathode material (i.e. nickel-manganese-cobalt in ratio 8:1:1, NMC811). Synthetic graphite as active material, silicon as coating material, carbon black as conductive additive, styrene butadiene (SBR) and carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) as binder are mixed in ration 92:2:1:2:3. Deionized water is used as solvent to prepare the anode slurry. The input materials are mixed to form a slurry, then the mixture is dried with the solvent evaporating away, cut and calendered to form the cathode of a Li-ion battery. The energy required to coat the copper conductor foil with the anode slurry is included in this dataset, because it was not possible to separate it from the energy required for the drying step.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The dataset is extrapolated from CN data; the uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: From Literature and expert judgement. The bill of material was taken from Dai et al. (2019), and adjusted to include carboxymethyl cellulose and styrene butadiene as binders, and silicon as coating. The energy consumption is dependent on the storage capacity of the LI-ion battery cell under study (see comments to exchanges)

flow.name: anode, silicon coated graphite, for Li-ion battery
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/27:Manufacture of electrical equipment/272:Manufacture of batteries and accumulators/2720:Manufacture of batteries and accumulators

exchanges.description: Based on expert judgement and literature. Synthetic graphite, carbon black, styrene butadiene, carboxymethyl cellulose and silicon are mixed in ration 92:1:2:3:2.

flow.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

defaultProvider.name: market for carbon black | carbon black | Cutoff, U
defaultProvider.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

exchanges.description:
Calculated value based on Pettinger & Dong (2016). Specifically, this value results from summing the energy demand for anode slurry preparation with water-based solvent, slitting and calendaring, in terms of kWh electricity per cell (0.331 kWh/cell). Original value refers to a 40 Ah, 3.7 V generic Li-ion battery, meaning 0.148 kWh energy density per cell. This data set considers the specific energy capacity of NMC811 cells (0.209 kWh/kg cell, calculated from Dai et al. 2018).
Reference:
Pettinger, K. H., & Dong, W. (2016). When does the operation of a battery become environmentally positive?. Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 164(1), A6274.
Dai, Q., Kelly, J. C., Dunn, J., & Benavides, P. (2018). Update of Bill-of-Materials and Cathode Materials Production for Lithium-Ion Batteries in the GREET Model. 2018. Argonne National Laboratory.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value based on Pettinger & Dong (2016). Specifically, this value results from summing the energy demand for anode slurry preparation with water-based solvent, slitting and calendaring, in terms of kWh electricity per cell (0.331 kWh/cell). Original value refers to a 40 Ah, 3.7 V generic Li-ion battery, meaning 0.148 kWh energy density per cell. This data set considers the specific energy capacity of NMC811 cells (0.209 kWh/kg cell, calculated from Dai et al. 2018).
Reference:
Pettinger, K. H., & Dong, W. (2016). When does the operation of a battery become environmentally positive?. Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 164(1), A6274.
Dai, Q., Kelly, J. C., Dunn, J., & Benavides, P. (2018). Update of Bill-of-Materials and Cathode Materials Production for Lithium-Ion Batteries in the GREET Model. 2018. Argonne National Laboratory.

Calculated value based on Pettinger & Dong (2016). Specifically, this value results from summing the energy demand for anode slurry preparation with water-based solvent, slitting and calendaring, in terms of kWh electricity per cell (0.331 kWh/cell). Original value refers to a 40 Ah, 3.7 V generic Li-ion battery, meaning 0.148 kWh energy density per cell. This data set considers the specific energy capacity of NMC811 cells (0.209 kWh/kg cell, calculated from Dai et al. 2018).
Reference:
Pettinger, K. H., & Dong, W. (2016). When does the operation of a battery become environmentally positive?. Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 164(1), A6274.
Dai, Q., Kelly, J. C., Dunn, J., & Benavides, P. (2018). Update of Bill-of-Materials and Cathode Materials Production for Lithium-Ion Batteries in the GREET Model. 2018. Argonne National Laboratory.

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical. 
References: 
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH. 
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.om ecoinvent)

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. The energy demand for anode drying & deionised water evaporation is between 10% (Susarla et al., 2018) and 50% (Pettinger & Dong, 2016) less than the energy required for cathode drying & NMP evaporation. An average 30% less energy demand than the energy required for NMC811 cathode was considered herein. The energy demand for anode drying and NMP evaporation is calculated considering the average value between 56 MJ/kWh cell and 71 MJ/kWh cell taken from Dai et al. (2017, referred to 43Ah, 3.7 V cells), the storage capacity per NMC811 cell (0.168 kWh/cell according to Dai et al., 2019) and the share of NMC811 cathode in the cell (37%)


Reference:
Pettinger, K. H., & Dong, W. (2016). When does the operation of a battery become environmentally positive?. Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 164(1), A6274.
Susarla, N., Ahmed, S., & Dees, D. W. (2018). Modeling and analysis of solvent removal during Li-ion battery electrode drying. Journal of Power Sources, 378, 660-670.
Dai et al. (2017). Update of Life Cycle Analysis of Lithium-Ion Batteries in the GREET Model. ArgonneNational Laboratory.
Dai et al. (2019). Life cycle analysis of lithium-ion batteries for automotive applications. Batteries, 5(2), 48.
